When pregnancy doesn't go well or ends in miscarriage or stillbirth, support from people who understand is tremendously important.  We were fortunate to benefit from a local miscarriage and newborn loss support group and found it invaluable.  I applaud your personal openness and the recognition you give to the importance of human support during a difficult time, a time with personal and professional impacts.  Best wishes to you.

That is great that you are confident enough to do so.  Please recognize you are privileged.  My friend had eight miscarriages.  Eight.  Then a stillbirth.  Do you think she should have announced her next (successful) pregnancy in the first trimester?  We struggled to conceive and had an early loss, then a difficult twin pregnancy that we did not know would last.  No way I was saying anything.

Yes, your piece recognizes that women don't tell for various reasons.  But the tone throughout is hectoring and preachy, as if women are somehow misperceiving the risk of telling.  We're not.

Not sharing is a social convention? Not to us. How about simply a couple choosing not to burden their family and friends with the anguish of a possible miscarriage? Dealing with it themselves if they are strong enough. If not, then share.

Now you've done it, you mentioned the alcohol thing.  The comments will be full of back and forth on it, dueling studies and mom guilt. 

But you're right, the alcohol police (and the coffee police) are one reason we are all tempted to quiet.  Nothing like having a hostess screech at you from halfway across the house in front of two dozen people at a Thanksgiving potluck dinner, "Hey, Di, you can't eat the cake Mark brought, it has rum in it!"

Um, thanks mommy!

I believe this message is very important.  It is not that every woman needs to share the news of an early pregnancy.  But, if more did it would help others deal with the high rate of miscarriages.  Women should not have to deal with the loss of a pregnancy alone: Unless they want to.  Thank you for breaking down a barrier.

With so many first pregnancies ending in miscarriage, it’s understandable that most women prefer to wait until the first trimester ends to disclose a pregnancy. While it would be wonderful to disclose such news at work and have a vast support system materialize, the reality of most workplaces is that disclosing a pregnancy triggers questions women may not be prepared to answer, and many unwelcome, intrusive questions that distract from her professional capabilities. As an executive coach with more than 15 years coaching this issue, I strongly advise women to bide their time, build a robust plan for managing the transition to and from maternity leave, and to consider all options germane to a negotiation about said leave. Only when they have their game plan in place, and it’s clear the pregnancy will likely continue do I encourage them to start selectively sharing the news. Timing of promotions and bonuses should also be factored into the plan. Until our country, and all it’s private and public institutions embraces women as equal contributors, the best approach is a strategic one.
Why is over-sharing the new norm?
I wish you well, and thank you for sharing your story.

As the saying goes, "you do you."  I'm not sure why you care so deeply that not everyone immediately announces a pregnancy.  They do it for their own reasons, and if all goes well, will announce it in their own time.

I remember when the ERA was first introduced and people were being scared by propaganda that women would have to use men's bathrooms and be assigned to combat in the military. We've come a long way on bathrooms and the military since then, but we still have a long way to go for women to get  meaningful equality. Women are still treated more harshly by many state judicial systems (Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee: I'm looking at your records on domestic violence). And as long as states try to control women's reproduction we are as far from equal as it gets.

I was with the thousands of other women in 1978 who marched on Washington for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment.  Some dressed as suffragettes and it was a sight to behold.  It was very disheartening when the amendment did not pass.  As the saying goes, better late than never.  I hope it passes now in my lifetime.

I marched for the ERA in the 70s and 80s and fought against the likes of Phyllis Schlafly and her regressive movement. I learned that often the biggest defenders of patriarchy are the women it favors with some small bit of token power. For those who would dismiss the importance of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution, and conclude it is just symbolic, I hope you live to see the day when women  generate their own power. The questions of who is nice enough, or electable enough, will be exposed for what they are.

Grateful to live to long enough to see this.  In 1975, I was an 18 year old UNC freshman. North Carolina Senator Sam Ervin's opposition to gender equality rights was fierce.  He said the ERA would be detrimental to women. I attended my first political march to bolster support for the ERA.  It was my first taste of political activism.  It was a fight we would not win...until now.

Under Scalia’s “originialist” interpretation, the 14th amendment was meant to protect the rights of newly freed male slaves, so it doesn’t protect women and other groups.

The ERA should be passed to clear this up.
Equal as in mathematically equal?   No way, no how.
Can we all just take a moment to appreciate the genius that is Ken Burns? He is an American treasure.
Gee, the time for ratification expired 10 years after the amendment was passed by both houses.  That would be some 30+ years ago.  Who cares?

Howze about women don't have to pay taxes till ERA passes? 

No one seems bothered by forcing women to cough up an equal share of their income  to pay for government bills, fund Pentagon Inc.'s misadventures, and take care of all the menz in prison.
Yes, the declarations are given by men.  Long live Affirmative Action....they will never be equal unless they take it.

Birch Bayh, senator from Indiana became Chairman of the Subcommittee on Constitutional Amendments, and in that role authored two constitutional amendments: the twenty-fifth—which establishes procedures for an orderly transition of power in the case of the death, disability, or resignation of the President of the United States—and the twenty-sixth, which lowered the voting age to 18 throughout the United States. He is the only non-Founding Father to have authored two constitutional amendments. Bayh also led unsuccessful efforts to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment and eliminate the Electoral College.

What about the men who have to fill in for her when they're out doing equal things like having a life and not working overtime or out on maternity leave? Will a man be able to sue a company when introduced, a female interviewer gives him a not in a million year look she would give too a guy like him in a singles bar? And when her boss supersedes her lack of judgement and hires the guy can he go to HR and complain when she turns everyone in the department against him? Does he get equal treatment?

But we see women need special treatment. Excuse me an amendment to prove they are equal. We have another example of a great Patriarchy  where a female MBA in charge of the pilot training of the 737 Max cut cost and took lives just like a man. (It was in Bloomberg). 

Let's here it for the ladies. Sorry, I mean women.

The ERA would forbid  gender based  affirmative action.

The original FEDERAL Constitution did NOT restrict suffrage to men.
Suffrage in a particular   state was to be determined by its state legislature.
Suffrage could have been limited to women.
The 19th amendment said BOTH sexes must have suffrage.

The amendment says:  Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.
So men, being a sex (or gender as we style it now), may no longer be denied the right to a legal abortion. Up until now only females have possessed this legal right and discrimination against the other sex will have to end. Men will gain the right to choose paternity at last just as women have in choosing maternity.

I supported the ERA since it was first proposed.  I also wrote a series of articles on its ratification and the issue of whether a state can rescind such ratification in our student publication, the University of Miami Hurricane, around 1974.   The topic of the expiration of the original seven-year deadline, nor the subsequent extension of that deadline, was then at issue.  I did practice law, but I don't pretend to be more than an amateur constitutional scholar.

So, not so fast Mr. Burns!  Your story tugs at my heartstrings, but my better judgment still reminds me that the ERA is still fraught with uncertainty.  There is no doubt that final determination of ERA - as first proposed and submitted by the Congress for ratification by the state legislatures in 1972 - is headed for the Supreme Court.

A majority of the Court can do the right thing and rule in favor of the ERA.  It would appear to be a case of first impression.  But the Court still needs either a legal basis and/or the courage to go against its political indebtedness.  Another, clearer option is to start over in Congress.  The results of the 2020 elections should provide a clue as to that likelihood.

And there are still many questions to be asked about its implementation.  Are women ready to assume not only the privileges given to men, but to carry the same burdons and responsibilities?  I hope so.  And I can't wait to take my main and only squeeze to dinner - Dutch treat - to celebrate!  May I live so long . . .

Beginning with the 20th Amendment, Congress has attached a time limit to the ratification of all proposed amendments, including the Equal Rights Amendment.  Some of these deadlines were in the language of the amendment itself. However, some of these deadlines, including the ERA, were in the proposing clause of the amendment.  

In 1978, Congress extended the ERA’s ratification deadline from March 22, 1979 to June 30, 1982, but that deadline has passed. So, even if Virginia votes to ratify the ERA, it would require a Supreme court decision that overrides previous decisions to become law.

This shows the power of the historical moment to inspire good decisions. While it doesn't always, sometimes a sense of history can propel a person to do what is right. When that doesn't seem to be happening, representative government must also incorporate the popular will. That's why I favor more ways for direct democracy to be taken into account nationally. Currently, popular sentiment (from climate change to changing social attitudes) is often out in front of Congressional performance. "We The People" were the first words of the Constitution.

Every single conservative who has claimed to be a strict constructionist should acknowledge the ratification of the ERA. Please read Article V. There is no provision for deadlines to be set by anyone or any body. Nor to allow ratifications to be withdrawn. Any claim by a self-styled "strict constructionist" that the ERA has not been ratified is simple hypocrisy. Let me help. Here is Article V in its entirety:

"The Congress, whenever two thirds of both Houses shall deem it necessary, shall propose Amendments to this Constitution, or, on the Application of the Legislatures of two thirds of the several States, shall call a Convention for proposing Amendments, which, in either Case, shall be valid to all Intents and Purposes, as Part of this Constitution, when ratified by the Legislatures of three fourths of the several States, or by Conventions in three fourths thereof, as the one or the other Mode of Ratification may be proposed by the Congress; Provided that no Amendment which may be made prior to the Year One thousand eight hundred and eight shall in any Manner affect the first and fourth Clauses in the Ninth Section of the first Article; and that no State, without its Consent, shall be deprived of its equal Suffrage in the Senate."

Does this mean women might be treated as equals, equal in pay, recognition, etc, etc, etc?  This sounds like a great change in law, but I doubt anything will change for those who already place women last unless women and supporters become more forceful. Besides, even the men in this country aren’t equal after 250 years. Ask any man of color. 

This nation will remain unequal as long as we allow haters, racist and sexists  to remain in leadership positions and until our Christian citizens learn how unChristlike we really are.  Sad to see them stoking the hatred.

It passed and thank goodness. Not because I am naive about what changes it could bring, not because I believe this vote is striking a blow against patriarchy (one need only turn one's head to find mediocre men talking over incredible women), but because slow progress is better than no progress. Yes, it's symbolic. And, what are symbols if not a sign for others to use as a means to connect and interface? These days, I'll take symbolic and run with it...all the way to the White House.
It is time! Pass the ERA!
Being declared equal and being treated equal are not the same thing. We're a long way from the latter.

So far the commenters seem to believe that the ERA will do everything short of curing cancer.  

It was an Issue, and People Fought About It.  But really, what is the change?  Can somebody point to a law that actually discriminates against one sex or the other?  The ERA will not address the equal pay issue, such as it is.   In fact, since it only applies to the framing of laws, it pretty much won't address any of the Popular Concerns.

And while we're in this area, we note that the same people in favor of ERA are happy to discriminate against voting citizens who happen to be under the age of 21.  Put that in you amendment and ratify it.
Useless, irrelevant virtue-signaling.

But remember, women, including Black women, were still discriminated against  for decades until Civil Rights legislation was passed in the 60’s.

Today is Martin Luther King’s Birthday.  Remember Rosa Parks, Amelia Boynton Robinson, and other women who led the way!

Funny, I always grew up under the impression that men were an inferior species...

I feel promoted!

:-))
It’s about time.
Oh, brother. Ladies, you are now equal. In fact, you're more than equal, you are superior. My wife is already well aware of that, just confirming it for general consumption.

The law is so short and vaguely worded as to be meaningless, or better yet capable of meaning virtually anything to any liberal judge who interprets it, which was no doubt the purpose of the Amendment in the first place.

Women have the same rights today as men, as guaranteed in the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment and the and the right to vote passed 100 years ago.

The problem is that no one knows what this Amendment means.  Putting such broad interpretive power in the hands of the judiciary may not be a good idea.

If it's only a "feel-good" thought, it doesn't need to be added to the Constitution.

Men and women have equal rights, but not the same rights. The right to be pregnant is equal but not the same as the right to fertilize. They both equally require consent, they both equally produce children. But being impregnated and giving birth nine months later is not the same as impregnating someone else.

Transgender women don’t have a right to be pregnant, only cis women and transgender men do.

God will be very happy.  She may even partially bless America.

 Will She be finally given Her dark African supernatural appearance in Christian theological depictions ? 

Ending all of the ignorant intemperate insecure misogyny and patriarchy about a male God with no mother nor wife nor daughter?

i simply do not understand why many people are against equal rights for women. i realize that many women feel that way. personally i think any politician who votes against equal rights for women should be run out of office as quickly as possible. they obviously are not good persons in my opinion.

Virginia, we're ALL LOOKING AT YOU:   ಠ_ಠ

Compare Eddie Gallagher to Medal of Honor winner (posthumously) Rodger Wilton Young from WWII.  

Private Young had voluntarily reduced his rank from Sergeant due to poor hearing, that would have gotten him sent back to the States.  (He didn’t want to make a poor decision that would hurt his platoon due to his hearing.)  In the days after landing on New Georgia Island in 1943, he died saving his comrades from almost certain death.  

He was part of a 20 man patrol in the jungle which was returning to base late in the day when it was ambushed and pinned down by five Japanese soldiers in a machine gun pit.  After other members of the patrol were killed by the Japanese and the lieutenant ordered the men to withdraw, Pvt. Young, already wounded in the ambush, began creeping forward.  The lieutenant ordered him to come back, but he replied that he could not hear the order due to his hearing loss and continued forward, where he was wounded again.  When he got close enough, he began lobbing grenades into the machine gun pit, causing several enemy casualties.  But, he was hit again while throwing and died from that wound.  His actions are credited with saving many members of the patrol.

As a Vietnam War Veteran, I believe the choices made by Pvt. Young show heroism, while those made by C.P.O. Gallagher disgrace this country.

During the American Revolution (our first civil war) General George Washington issued an order that prisoners would be treated humanely, wounds attended to , fed, etc as best they could. This was at a time when our prisoners were concentrated on rotting hulks in New York harbor left to fend for themselves. Also at this time the accepted practice by European armies was to dispatched the wounded left on the battlefield with the bayonet. The Hessians were particularly cruel. 
Washington recognized that the ideals upon which the revolution was begun as well as the words of the Declaration of Independence had to be exemplified in the continental army’s operations. (This may  have  part of the reason that fully 20 percent of the Hessians remained in America after the war.
My attraction in pursuing a military career was the understanding that our armed forces were a force for good. That honor was important. Learning, understanding and abiding by the law of armed conflict was important to maintain that ethos, and our humanity and stay in connection with the ideals set forth in our founding documents and operationalized by Washington during the revolution. Friedman writes: "When administrations are not constantly forced to answer hard questions from the outside about what they’re thinking strategically and morally — when questioners are dismissed as unpatriotic — that administrations’ inside thinking gets sloppy, their intelligence gets manipulated and trouble follows"

True--and that's why we have sunshine laws, like my state's Inspection of Public Records Act and Open Meetings Act.

However, Friedman also writes: "Never assume that people who are in charge know what they are doing just because they are in charge."

Actually, our tripartite, constitutional democracy expressly assumes precisely the opposite, and the fact that Friedman ignores the rule of law in favor of some moral imperative as the fundamental principle grounding our Great Experiment belies either his ignorance or rejection of America's raison d'etre.

If, as Friedman urges, morality were to supplant the rule of law, then two things would be inevitable: (i) the majority's definition of what is moral would prevail, gutting the protection of dissent that is enshrined in the Constitution; and (ii) the First Amendment's prohibition on the establishment of a state religion would quickly become meaningless--as indeed William Barr and others are vigorously attempting even now.

Trump has a "code of dishonor". But the phrase implies more sanity than he exhibits. And let's stop calling his actions "erratic behavior." The man is frankly insane. And his reckless, ignorant actions will result in the deaths of thousands before he is gone. Trump has this nation careening into an abyss that will take decades to recover from. Our nation is now entirely isolated. We are now the country that is the international pariah. 

Trump's actions are now an existential threat to this nation. That he acts dishonorably is the least of our problems now. He knows his base will believe any lie he tells, even when those lies conflict. 

Trump has publicly called for his military to commit internationally recognized war crimes. Any decent American ought to have been sickened by those statements. He has shredded the very fabric of this nation, and destabilized the world in just three short years. And trying to ascribe Trump's actions as some sort of "code of dishonor" gives too much credence to the term. 

If Trump is not stopped now, he will wreak absolute destruction on our country. Do not expect Trump voters to "come to their senses". They like everything their "president" does, regardless of the damage it does to our nation. They have decided to cast their lot with an insane man. 

Expect America, in the not too distant future then, to look much like post WWII Germany as it had to shed its Nazi past and re-join the community of civilized nations. Our nation is gone.

We have been waging the endless war for a full century now but the free press believes Donald Trupm is the source of our problems.

No, he isn't.

The incumbent is just a consequence of them.

To eliminate the problems we must finally cope with the cause.

Do we understand what's making us wage the endless wars?

All one has to do is observe how the Prime Minister of Canada, Justin Trudeau, is dealing with the downing of the Ukrainian aircraft that resulted in the death of 57 of his fellow citizens, and then imagine how trump would react if any Americans had been among the casualties. trump set in motion the actions that resulted in this tragedy. Unfortunately, trump is power mad and out of control and the world is far less safe for his total lack of morals and integrity.

This column really connects the dots about Trump and his mentality...there are 3 people who really need to read this and have an epiphany. But neither Trump or Gallagher will do that, and Suleimani can't.
If he profits financially, it is a good deal. He was afraid of another Benghazi, and hence, he had to act NOW. There is no strategy.

Trump understands the use of symbols, for good or ill:  
1.  Suleimani, a symbol for his policies towards his Iranian enemy and terrorism more generally.
2.  The Wall, a potent symbol of anti-immigrant policy.
3.  Forgiving Gallagher, signaling the type of warrior he favors.
4.  The stock market, as the most important yardstick for economic success.

Note that using all of these powerful symbols communicates in ways that extensive whitepapers cannot.  Democrats need to learn to battle symbol-for-symbol.

Suleimani vs. the picture of the Canadian newlyweds who died along with 174 others on the Iranian aircraft shot down, potent symbols of Trump's recklessness.

Pictures of the those who were massacred at Sandy Hook, a potent symbol for gun control.

Personalize the intangible.
"He lacks a clear moral or strategic framework."  You're right...but he's going to pivot.

Trump plans to campaign with Gallagher, using him as a prop to prove Trump's devotion to our military "heroes."  And I expect that thousands will fill venues to hear Trump and witness the "hero" tagging along with him.  When speaking of a moral framework, it's not only Trump who lacks it, it's those who come to listen and applaud his moral defects.

There is no plan with Trump, it is all in the moment and what will benefit him the most  Right now his focus is on Impeachment and his reelection.   The Suleimani assassination was designed to distract from Impeachment and strengthen his 'tough guy' image for reelection.  The fact that it led to the shooting down of a Ukrainian airliner and 176 death means nothing to Trump, it did not effect him.

Trump is in way over his head and is damaging our nation and our relations around the world.  We must get rid of him to prevent further damage, either through Impeachment of by the elections.

There comes a day when each one of us loses it watching Trump act. Witnessing a one with such blatant immorality in the act of exploiting sanctioned US power to cause great harm is exactly what the platoon members experienced with Gallagher. Not calling it for what it was simply became impossible:  visceral outrage to  immorality must be expressed. 

I feel this is what Mr. Friedman is here doing as well. The disbelief of what one is witnessing is soon overcome by the need to shout aloud.

Know what? I don't care about psychobabble analysis of Trump's inner being. I care about policies and results. And so far his policies and results are not only mainstream Republican but vastly better than Obama's, who may very well have had a marvelous "moral and strategic framework". No President has ever been subjected to such vicious and corrupt attempts to overthrow him from the very day he was elected.  He has not only defeated them but also found time to implement successful policies.

Despite the evidence that every day, every minute, assaults my eyes and my brain, I still find it extremely difficult to believe that evil on the scale that trump represents is now an acceptable norm for our country.  Yes, trump has absolutely no sense of right and wrong and believes that greed and fear are the only true human motivators. And I believe that there are others like him in the world. But that trump is the president of our country and is idolized by a substantial proportion of the population...  I simply cannot understand how we got to this point.
Make America prosperous and safe is the big goal. And he succeeded beyond expectations, working with hands tied by the Democrats. Like Houdini...

Remember that coat Melania wore that caused a brief uproar - "I don't care.  Do you?"  Well, it's time to ask ourselves - do we care?  Do we care who we are?  Do we care how we are represented?  Do we care how we are perceived by the civilized world?  Do we care about our children, and all the children of this world?  The shocking thing, the repulsive thing, is that half apparently do not.  And that cannot endure.  And we will not if we allow this to continue.  Of that I am certain.

For too long a time, Trump and his supporters have made me ashamed to be an American. His evangelical supporters have made me question why my own parents were so intent on bringing me up as an evangelical. At times, they have all led me to think things might have been better for the world if my ancestors had never stepped off the Mayflower. But those were all just inchoate thoughts. Now the depths of their depravity has come fully into focus. Increasingly, the whole lot of them make me ashamed to be a human.
We can't continue to impel our military into many nations without an inevitable reckoning.

I am grateful that Mr. Friedman has so eloquently expressed what, to me and countless others, has been clear for years, well before he even got into politics: the only code of conduct that governs your president is self-interest.  

Lacking anything that resembles an honour code based in the collective interests of the society or country pretty much makes Trump feral.  

The president of the United States is that most rare of individuals: a feral human animal.  Imagine that.  Perhaps come next November, your electorate might want to bring an end to this three-ring circus presidency.  PLEASE.
It frightens me to think what he might do  in mid October to secure his election.

The president may be First among Equals, but everyone in the USA is subject to the law.   By not acknowledging this, Republicans are giving the green light to people like Gallagher and his friends at Fox the right to break the laws that made America Great.  
Who knew that we wold have to recycle Trump's MAGA HATS after his term is finished.   Whether it is through impeachment, loss of the 2020 election, or, God for Bid, another 4 year term, eventually we will have to MAKE AMERICAN GREAT AGAIN.

I think it’s ironic that so many in the military, who are generally honorable and ethical Americans, tend to also be ardent Republicans.  I attended last year’s Army / Navy game, and it kind of felt like a Trump rally, but for educated people.  How can people of honor keep supporting this horrible man and the party that he clearly controls?

The trump brand is clearly fading. As EX military and a member of several FB groups i see it happening right before my eyes. Instead of snarky comments to dissenters with views against trump, the comments are starting to parse these comments. Embarrassing decisions like this one will stop him cold in the military. We have a honor code of conduct, unlike him.

Edward Gallagher is precisely the kind of guy Trump would love--a tough, violent guy who made his own rules and lived by them. Trump, too, fancies himself as this kind of man, as shown by his repeated treatment of the world's most vile dictators like members of a high school clique he is desperate to be admitted to.  

So if you are a Navy Seal who often operates in a gray zone bound largely by patriotism, tradition, a code of honor and the respect and trust of your fellow Seals, what now bounds you? The Commander in Chief just gleefully pardoned a Seal whom you saw commit heinous acts in violation of all of those standards, and then feted him at his mansion like he was a conquering hero. 

So much of our society is held together not by laws or force, but by the basic decency and morality ingrained in us that we demonstrate every day in how we go about our lives. Trump's choices and actions with Gallagher show, yet again, that he is neither decent nor moral.

We don't need a better nuclear deal with Iran.

We need the peace with Tehran.

We need the peace with North Korea too.

Isn't it long overdue after seven decades passed by?

If there is no peace between the two sides and one of them is dramatically stronger, then the responsibility is always on the stronger side for the lack of stability and cooperation.

Our elite forces live by a code, as do all Americans, the constitution. We are a country of laws and strive to be country of ideals to set examples for the world. However as we are all learning, leadership comes from the top. As this commander in chief could not be trusted to make rational decisions( something the intelligence community and members of Congress have also learned) the Seals were in fact left with no choice but to defy and revolt against this president’s leadership in protesting his pardoning of Gallagher and his atrocious violations which went against the code of conduct they tried to live by. War is not all killing randomly just for sport as these brave soldiers have shown, and even under such terrible circumstances they are able to keep a sense of right and wrong. How tragic Trump has a paranoid world view unless something’s in it for him it doesn’t matter what happens to anyone else. I’d say we need more diplomacy to solve problems in our foreign affairs but he’s also gutted our diplomatic service.

Sadly, CPO Gallagher's actions are par for the course in what must be 8,000 years of recorded history as far as warfare is concerned.

"The Greatest Generation" had a large number of Gallaghers in it.  You simply didn't read about those incidents in your history books.  We know, however, from those same books that the Japanese and Germans had plenty of Gallaghers and we diligently went after them.

There are Gallaghers among the noble Kurds.  And without overly insulting my own heritage, I'd venture to say that there are even outwardly polite Canadian Gallaghers whose teammates simply haven't reported them.

And the pardoning of all of these Gallaghers is not uncommon, as Mr. Friedman suggests.  Start with Wikipedia, look up US War Crimes, and follow the links to see how many times U.S. Servicemembers routinely got away with overt mass murder.

The day has changed.  Still nothing new under the Sun though.

I teach philosophy in a maximum security prison. One of the men has been facilitating groups of inmates on the Code of the Warrior, about honor, ethics, and personal integrity.
In a different venue in the community, a 20 year veteran of the army, in an ethics class, reviewed the Trump/Gallagher affair.
In both places these men expressed disappointment and disgust at the absence of dignity or respect.
The fact that felons find the behavior and attitude of the president deficient, and a veteran after three tours in Iraq sees the commander in chief a negative role model, sparks serious reflection about the moral and ethical problems on display for all to see.

The ideas cannot be killed by the guns or guided missiles. 

The ideas can only be destroyed by the better ideas. 

I offered this simple recipe to defeat the terror in a thousand times cheaper and ten times faster way over the last couple of decades but nobody needed it. 

Yes, the rise of the terrorism could have been predicted and preempted but nobody cared.
But Trump represents 40% of Americans. It is the fact that they approve of these behaviors that’s the problem, not Trump.

Yes, there is a moral framework and a strategic framework. And there is also legal framework.Why so shy about addressing this? Is it because the Us as an 'exceptional'  state writes its own laws? Surely not for it depends as Friedman says, on reciprocity.

The rest of the world accepts that the US is a democracy that can change its leaders. Until recently, this was a modest concern. Foreign countries could assume that, no matter who occupied the office, the world could rely on the President to do certain things.  

The current President, and the American electorate, have made it clear that a foreign country is making a mistake to assume a deal with one administration binds the next administration. Sad to say, this is going to be a bigger problem for your next President than for the current President.

Look up the definition of politician and underline the part where it’s mentions moral framework.  I must have missed it.  Then look back on the past Administration and highlight strategic accomplishments if you find any.

The heroes are the Seals who, under unimaginable stress and pressure maintained their honor, found Gallagher's actions monstrous, and reported him. We should be honoring them but instead Trump honors Gallagher.

"Never assume that people who are in charge know what they are doing just because they are in charge."

Being in charge trumps knowing what you are doing.  
For example, when Trump says, "I did nothing wrong," referring to blackmailing Mr. Zelenskyy is he speaking as Donald Trump, a man with no credibility who is denying that he had committed a crime, or as POTUS and stating a fact based on his power as chief executive, "By executive powers, I determine what is a fact.  'I did nothing wrong,' is not a denial but an executive order.   "I cannot tell a lie" does not mean that George Washington was honest, but that a president, who is the single voice of all the people in a democracy, is incapable of lying for the people determine what is true.  People like the idea that Trump was taking absolute responsibility for them.  They didn't care if he knew what he was doing.  It was never about him.  It was about their need to subordinate themselves to a voice that had an answer for everything, was male, white, and owned properties built by people he reduced to the status of slave simply by getting richer by not paying them.

Thank you, Mr. Friedman. I confess I had not been following the Gallagher story as I (wrongly) assumed it involved some breach of arcane military regulations in the "fog of war". I had no idea that Gallagher was (credibly) accused of randomly shooting an adolescent girl in the stomach and stabbing a sedated teenage captive in the neck, among other crimes.

And Mr. Trump INVITED this man over to Mar-a-Lago for Christmas, a day for commemorating Jesus and all the good that he stands for? Why? Why? Why?

If we ever return to something like moral normalcy here in this country, with a morally centered President and Senate,
three of the first things we should do are:
1. restore obligatory national service, military or societal.
How many times have I heard friends reflect that it was their military service that matured them, helped them adjust to the world and become a productive part of society. 
We learn to work together in an organization.
It would also give us a chance to identify some of those with serious mental problems and treat some of them before they  become completely lost and violent.
2. restore the equal time rule in the media, so that the lies and propaganda so well financed by the corporate rulers,  will not continue to dominate our national discourse, in spite of Citizens United. And if corporations are citizens, they should have societal obligations too, not just rights. 
3. return to the generous funding of our state universities, to reduce the need for expensive student loans and lower the cost of higher education.
Educated citizens aren't so easily manipulated. 
The restoration of these three things, which were strategically, intentionally devalued and thrown out, would help us again to be more of a united states.

The pardoning of Gallagher is a disgrace to any moral standard. But to say that the American armed forces are always directed by a high moral standard no matter how heated the battle is an exaggeration and historically incorrect. Browse through major 'incidents' in Vietnam, such as the massacre of MaiLai. But also many a wedding bombed to pieces in Afghanistan, and indiscriminate bombing in the so called liberation of Iraq from Saddam Hussein. And not to forget Abu Ghraib and Guantanamo Bay. The list can go on. No American commander has ever been prosecuted for alleged war crimes. In fact the US stays with abstention from endorsing the ICJ in fear of American soldiers to be prosecuted for Iviolations of International Humanitarian Law, better known as the Geneva Conventions. How does that match with moral standards?

After three consecutive years of 'Code Blue' (in medical terminology, an emergency situation in which a patient is in need of immediate resuscitative efforts), we've now entered into 'Code Purple,' when emergency reinforcements are required to sustain the patient.  Prognosis:  Poor.  
We all know the causes and the symptoms, yet we still seem helpless and hopeless to prevent the imminent destruction of our democracy by our own citizens as well as by our most formidable sworn enemies.  
Unless we vote.

Gallagher plays well with his base who believe Trump is a savior from the deep state.    Attacking Trump's morality or lack thereof also allows Trump to argue that the liberal elite continue to thumb their noses at real Americans.   As long as people continue think they are better than any Trump supporter, the country will remain divided.

His handling of the Gallagher case encapsulates Trump's lack of moral judgment and his inability to understand the larger impact on military morale and discipline.  However, these failings are not news.  We knew with certainty Trump's lack of morality when he separated children and infants from their families at the border with no system of reuniting them.  And we knew with certainty that he had no strategic framework when he started denigrating NATO and its member countries.

I think all this goes back to some humans inability to exercise a fully developed concept of empathy. They see anyone different or not a member of their tribe as less worthy of humanity than their own ideal of humanity. This is trait seems to be linked with conservatives more so than liberal thinkers, but not exclusively so. It is at the root of many of humanities worst periods of chaos and slaughter. I know people much smarter than me have wrestled with this concept for a couple thousand years so I don’t anticipate a solution in the short term but recognising it and analysing these feeling when they pop into your thought processes would be a step in the right direction. 

In short humans are tribal by nature and this nature can be harnessed for both good and evil.

And if tomorrow the protests in Iran were to escalate into a civil war, what would that lead to? Looking at what has happened in the mid East in the past years, from Libya, Egypt to Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan, how can anybody think that would end well (for the Iranians).
Ouch. Trumps grandstanding will have spillovers. It is just a question of when and how much.

I was not surprised by Trump's actions regarding  Gallagher.
The presidency exposes for all to see the true character of the individual sitting  behind the Resolute desk. He does not give any credence to what his actions will bring forth.  He could care less about the Constitution and honoring his oath.  In many ways Trump is still that cadet in the military school that he was sent to as a child.

I think that Friedman, who has some expertise in Middle 
East affairs, may be equating two different issues in his effort to make a point.
The Suleimani assassination was an absolute must for deterrence and justice. Ridding the world of this mass murderer-monster of Americans, Iranians, and thousands of others the assassination shows a positive Trump learning curve  since his recognized and mistaken signals of retreat in late 2019.
The Gallagher issue must be addressed by the President. He will be forced to reconsider his previous evaluation of a clearly dangerous American officer.

Having served 30 years in the military I can say this is a good op ed.  Thank you.  Trump is a symptom and not the root cause.  I would add that the actions of the Bush administration in response to 9-11 and the inactions of the Obama administration are also reprehensible and are and will subject us to terrible blowback.  I have often felt that when the history books are written centuries from now, long after the US is but a memory, Bin Laden will be characterized as one of the greatest military leaders in history.  With 15 men he took down the greatest power of the time....equivalent to Rome even.  The devastation of 9-11 was nothing compared to the devastation we have brought on ourselves in South Asia with no end in sight.  It is hard to imagine Bin Ladin envisioned the degree of self destruction the US was capable of but maybe he did.

Thomas Friedman is completely in the right to call out the lack of any moral compass in Donald Trump, but the last sentence in this piece is missing the point. It doesn't matter because the same thing can happen to Americans. It matters because you just don't treat others like that, no matter their ethnicity, nationality or religion. Any person lacking the very basic humanity to condemn behavior like that should not lead anyone.

Everyone knows what Trump is like. But what is really awful, and why he is still in office, is that supposedly reputable Republicans line up and support him. No just one but almost all-and that my friends is the real danger. A significant portion of our legislative branch has let America down. There are a number of significant cases before the Supreme Court this session and the judiciary, for the most part, has been rendering decisions that have clear legal  reasoning. However and hopefully the majority of the Court will not use twisted legal logic to avail Trump a victory.

I'd like to say it blows my mind that he still enjoys the solid support of the evangelical community in the USA, but I guess all I can say is, "it's too bad". I don't know how they square support for the man with their goals and (purported) ideals.

This what makes me disgusted with Mr. Trump. This piece should be something that the campaign coming up will show any voter who unlike Trump does have standards. I used to be a scout leader and at that time the BSA was a beacon for every young man I had the privilege to lead. They were full of it of course but they carried the standards of their bring up and I was glad to be part of what we were doing. So how did Mr. Trump reach his sordid set of values? My sister who trained at Bellevue and become nurse tells me that in their psychology class, Trump's behavior is that of a Sociopath which used to describe a person like him. The standards of such description were weakened recently and so now the term is not used any more. I think the term needs to be re-invoked and applied for us all to understand that such a person really believes every thing he does in OK. Even though his belief can suddenly change as the mind come upon its next belief so its OK to say or do most anything without a firm set of standards to under score what he is doing. Much is made of his lies but to him they are not lies at all since they are for a while in his mind. The cure does not exist for this condition and it is not know what causes it. Meanwhile we endure a man who can't help him self, it seems.

Trump way of working is to wade in with a wrecking ball, mess everything up and then back off and let others sort out the mess. In the reshuffling sometimes things get sorted out, sometimes not. Trump takes huge credit both ways. He keeps this up until some folks believe it. Meanwhile, he moves on to something else with the wrecking ball. He never looks back, does not count the cost, makes up what he wants to say and lets others pick up the pieces behind him.
 Collateral damage is all around him, but he never notices. He wants the limelight, either way he wins in his mind. There is an attempt at oversight that is sometimes noticed, as when Trump reads something written not by him to the general public. But he soon goes back to his normal behaviour. These forays are often distractions from unpleasant reactions to something he just did. the new action is to draw attention away from his mess somewhere else. 
This is what we have for our most powerful position in the country. A wrecking ball mentality. 
Are we good with this ?

Really? The purpose of war is first to win the war as quickly and cheaply as possible. Some armies have been more scrupulous in following the 'rules of war' than others, but no country or alliance is totally moral, to use your word.
Wars between nations are not just battles between armies. Winning as quickly as possible always - ALWAYS - involves breaking the resolve of the civilians who support the armed forces. The North victory in our civil war involved Sherman's march through Georgia. The Allied victory in WWII included the firebombing of Dresden where, 20 minutes after the first wave of bombers rained explosives on the city, when the civilians came out on the streets to survey the damage, a second wave of bombers attacked the city...which was not a military target. And after taking 90% casualties in the first hour of the Normandy invasion, as German machine gun emplacements were overrun, no Germans who attempted to surrender survived.
The Wehrmacht was incredibly brutal, more than Allied troops, but our side committed numerous violations of the Geneva Convention. 
Finally, wars are won when the losing side is convinced that further engagement is suicidal. The winners are feared. Honor has little to do with it.
That said, when a Gallagher is honored, we as a nation suffer as a consequence, but that is true because we are not involved in a full-scale war. We do not have an objective, a strategy for victory, or a declaration of war. What we have is a recipe for confusion.

What is really concerning is how Mr. Trump  has struck an apparent preexisting acceptance of vitriol, hate, prejudice, crassness and sense of superiority in his supporters. Their ends justifying the "means" rationale strikes at their basic indecency. Make America Great Again - indeed.

Good column about the lack of morality of our commander in chief. 

Now, I feel a bit upset with the glorification of the "code" our military exemplifies (in contrast to out of control Gallagher type). 
Lets get real here, 500K+ Iraki death with a very large fraction of that civilians is not honorable at all. So "rating" out someone gunning down civilians for "fun" is good, but from there to saying our military has admirable moral character is a bridge to far. 

Shock and Awe and the doctrine of overwhelming force sounds good when you are not on the side getting shelled part of the acceptable co-lateral damage. 

War are messy that why we should not start them in the first place. Saying there are honorable soldiers does not change the fact that these soldiers are sent into preemptive invasions of country that did not attack us. [WMD what ?]. The top layer of the military has clearly no morality.

The problem is far greater than Trump immorality, our military industrial complex is also deeply immoral and has done a great job shaping our culture away from humanist ideals.

Glad you're finally picking up on the Gallagher story, even if it's a month and a half after Trump's pardon.  I think it's helpful to remind everyone, particularly the Republican cohort, about this sad story.  I believe many Republicans are honorable people, so I do wonder how they view this incident and stay loyal to Trump.

From the beginning of Trump's presidency, he's shown no awareness of ethics or moral structure. It has been blatantly obvious, from giving Russian visitors classified information, to the kidnapping of immigrants' children, to taking multimillion-taxpayer-dollar holidays at Mar-a-Lago, to fighting to hide his tax returns (the reasons must surely be impeachable), to alienating allies while sweet-talking dictators, to pressuring the Ukrainian president to find a way to weaken a political adversary, to undermining government protection of land and clean water and air, to rejection of scientific research in climate change and other vital fields, to lying and lying and lying--well, I could go on, but so could anyone who isn't part of his dazzled Base. We should just be glad that he managed to dodge the draft--who knows what damage he might have done if he'd been involved in Vietnam.

Here's the thing. Trump is a calamity no matter how you slice him. That the economy is still on a roll (sorry Republicans) isn't an indication of his success, it merely means he hasn't broken it yet. So while I appreciate Mr. Friedman's perspective and understand the necessity for his opinion piece there is no new news here. Trump has reached out his hand and what he's touched has turned to... So what else is new?

Looks like there is a strategy to divide the military against itself in yet another bid for loyalty to Trump over the Constitution, our laws, and now military codes of conduct. This is a huge threat to America as we know it.

Trump has a very strong moral core.  You can tell if you listen to his speeches from beginning to end and observe how the audience interacts with him.  He does not utter pieties and say the correct things.  He is joking a lot of the time in a way that is engaging and entertaining.  But there is no doubting his moral convictions.  A style of rhetoric that is appealing and utterly convincing to those who leave their liberal prejudices at the door.

At some point, the American president, congress, Pentagon and intelligence agencies are going to need to come to grips with the fact that sending troops to the mideast, assassinating “terrorist leaders, and interfering in the internal politics of sovereign mideastern states is never going to end fundamentalist Islamic terrorism.
We have been meddling in the affairs of these countries to insure a steady flow of oil to the US for a very long time. Hasn’t this business far surpassed the point of diminishing returns?
Is it really in our interest to continue riling folks up to the point where they wrap themselves in explosives and become suicide bombers?

Perhaps we should declare the assassination of General Suleimani and his nine companions to be the final chapter in our involvement in a long 
violent struggle that has cost so much, harmed so many and, finally come to have no clear purpose?

"Evil, be thou my good"

or

"Better to reign in hell than to serve in heaven"

I think it's a waste of energy to try to find anything but greed, exploitation and vanity there, along with a healthy dose of hate promotion and victim blaming.

The criteria for the impeachment and removal from office of an American president may not be crystal clear, except for the most serious high crime of treason, which is narrowly defined because it is a capital offense.

Reckless action by an American president which brings dishonor upon the United States and which also costs the unnecessary loss of life of American military and civilian personnel ought to be grounds for removal. 

When such dishonorable acts cause the deaths of citizens of countries which are our allies, those acts should be cause for removal.

Thomas Friedman is right. Honor is a concept which has no meaning to Donald Trump. Every day Trump is issuing orders and official pronouncements at the White House -- or even making off-the-cuff remarks at rallies or to reporters – this president diminishes and endangers America.

Friedman is exactly correct in his conclusion.  I wonder what percentage of soldiers realize that by giving Gallagher a free pass Trump has virtually ensured that they, too, will be treated inhumanely if and when they are captured by the enemy.  Some do, but many do not.  For the latter I will shed no tears when their time comes.

Strange observations on the meaning of a moral code, Mr Friedman. I believe the correctness of your statements all the way to your last point. Then you join the club of simple-mindedness that you accuse Trumpians of being. How does morality have to do with anything, especially in wartime? Our culture's conditioned response to aggression is to reciprocate with even more ferociousness. Do you sincerely believe that in spite of our "higher moral standing" we should engage in violence? I go back to the hippie thing of what if they gave a war and nobody came. 
But then again evidently you believe in "good wars", i.e. Iraqi invasion number two. There is a belief among some older military officers from the Viet Nam era who in their guilt of murder have convinced themselves and a whole lot of other civilians from later generations that it is ok, even necessary to annihilate the enemy. Wow. What do you think the enemy's next generation is going to believe?
Morality is a convenience of afterthought. Another old hippie thing,"make peace not war". War, murder, amorality are cheap and easy for those who believe in it, making peace appears impossible, and is impossible if you don't believe it will work.

Being praised by Trump and feted at Mar-a-Lago apparently isn't enough for the pardoned war criminal ego.  The other day there was an article right here in the Times that mentioned Gallagher's undertaking to profit on his notoriety by marketing a line of trinkets and memorabilia celebrating himself and his "knife skills".  

I find that appalling, if not obscene. And I'm thinking Gallagher and Trump must see one another as kindred spirits.

Years ago, I was a student at the University of Munich. I studied under a professor who was also the director of the Bavarian State Archives. He allowed me to do research there on topics he assigned me. 

One evening, my wife and I were dinner guests at his home. During the course of conversation, he revealed that he had been on the Eastern Front in Operation Barbarossa. He was in army intelligence. Reports of soldiers shooting Ukrainian civilians were flowing steadily into his headquarters. At first, he did not believe them. Later, once he had been up close to Wehrmacht conquests of villages in which he saw soldiers shoot men, women, and children, he knew that war crimes had been committed. He had seen several mass murders. He told us that most Germans would not believe such stories; their soldiers could not have committed such atrocities. But he knew better.

Our armed forces have striven to live by high moral and ethical codes at the risk to their lives on the battle fields. Men have died trying to abide by codes of conduct when they might have had a chance to waste a whole village as Lt. Calley did in Mai Lai. Now, Sgt. Gallagher steps out of the ranks of his fellow SEALS and into the arms of our amoral president who is more interested in using him as a symbol of his personal power to challenge Navy military rules and codes of conduct. My professor in Munich would have recognized Gallagher. He is a brother of the same spear as those in the Wehrmacht and Waffen-SS.

A professional soldier like those in the SEAL teams are trained to kill quickly and without hesitation because that it necessary. They are not trained to seek opportunities to kill or focus upon killing because focusing upon that distracts from their completing their missions effectively.

What Gallagher did was lose his sense of morality and his professionalism, both. He became obsessed with killing and by doing so was not focusing upon his job but upon his own demons. 

The counter productive nature of cruelty and unnecessary brutality done in order to terrorize or to punish hostile populations by an occupier were clearly displayed during WWII by the Germans in Eastern Europe and the SS and Gestapo in Western Europe. When Hillary did not “win“ the election I looked at how many females around the world have won popular elections to lead countries. There have been very, very few. The ones who have, usually have some connection to some previous leader (a Ghanaian or a Peron) almost like royalty ascending to the throne. 

Many of the female leaders throughout Europe have been elected by coalitions in the ministries, where the populace has not placed them in office, but they have been chosen by representatives (almost like Nancy Pelosi). 

If you look at a number of states in this country you see that they have never elected a woman governor. These states highlight how backward some portions of this country are. We have come along way, but there is still a way to go for women to be treated as the equal to men.

Elizabeth has "a policy for everything" and an answer to every question, the gift of gab, but that is not what most people are looking for in a president. People are looking for a thoughtful person who is a good listener, and who really does not have a policy for everything.

Unfortunately, we still have women who vote against their own interests. We also have men who will never, ever vote for a woman. Show them virtually any two candidates who have the same qualifications, and it will come down to race and/or gender. Are we absolutely sure that the Bernie voters who voted for Trump over Hillary did so to vote against the establishment? Or do you think there was a tinge or sexism involved? I do. You can't credibly argue with someone about something you both strongly agree on.

They’re the big winners here, but they couldn’t have possibly guessed that Warren and Sanders would take the bait and go after each other, could they? A Republican? I doubt that they fear a left-wing Democratic candidate. I just don’t get it, but it’s the only part of this mishegoss that I’m interested in.

There are two distinct concepts at play here.  The first is whether or not certain immutable traits will cost the candidates votes.  The second is whether a candidate is "electable."  The first is a statistical objective fact, but the former says very little about the latter, and is certainly not determinative of it.
Let's examine the first issue.  This is NOT a debatable point.  A woman candidate will lose a not-insignificant numbers of votes based on the fact that she is a woman, much in the same way as Obama lost votes based on the fact that he was black.  These are cold hard statistical facts; denying them is akin to denying that sexism and racism exist.
However, as the Obama presidency proves, clearly race is not a determinative factor for electability, it just depends on whether the candidate can inspire more voters to show up through his/her message, and yes even through the assistance of his/her race/gender.
The lesson to take from the Clinton loss is NOT that a woman candidate is unelectable.  The big difference between Obama and Clinton was that not only could Obama use his race to get out the minority vote, but his message of CHANGE was also an inspiration that energized the Democratic side.  In contrast, sure Clinton lost votes based on sexism, but I'm sure she also attracted votes of additional women because of her gender.  Her problem was she didn't inspire enough people to vote because she never articulated what she actually stood for beyond the status quo.

That's a silly reply to a silly suggestion--it's akin to saying that a fighter with a tiny but undefeated record is a superior boxer to someone who hasn't been befeated in 30 years of fighting but lost some early bouts.
Take Klobuchar as an example.  She dropped out of the first election she entered so technically not a loss.  She was then elected DA twice, the second time unopposed. She then won three senate races.  
Good record, but lets compare her to Sanders, who wore the brunt of these attacks.  Sure he lost long-shot races in 1972, 1974, and 1976, and again a race for mayor in 1980.  But since then?  He won three mayoral races, lost one Congressional race, but then one it (against an incumbent) two years later, winning a total of 8 races (1991-2007), and then won another two times running for U.S. Senate.  So that's a total of 13 successful campaigns for Sanders vs Klobuchar's relatively paltry 5 (one being unopposed).
Warren's record is even more limited in comparison, having only had 2 successful campaigns.
As such, Sanders' very reasonable response should have been that he has been in continuous elected posts since 1981, with the exception of two years.   I.e. Klobuchar was in university when he first got elected as mayor, and Warren was still a professor.

I hear what @TJ is saying about being a 'moderate democrat', if by moderate you mean not spending money simply for spending's sake, but when the concept of moderate means that policies like universal health care coverage, realistic family leave policies, broader access to higher education, higher minimum wages, stronger environmental policies, and being open to immigrants are 'too expensive' or 'make it too easy for folks', I have to strongly disagree. All of those things work successfully (or at least relatively so, given that there are NO perfect governments) in other Western countries. Why can't we find ways to make them work in the US. As an American living in Norway, I can tell you that the quality of life is significantly better than in the US because of the flexibility that universal health care provides with respect to choosing or changing jobs and the work-life balance that is supported by parental leave policies, options that allow people with disabilities to work part time, and minimum wages that actually allow one to live. Although my taxes are high, they are probably about the same, if not lower than what I would pay in the US if I added health insurance payments to what my US taxes would be on an equivalent amount of income. I can believe that Sanders thinks that a woman is capable of governing as president, & that he also believes that a woman won't be elected to the office. Notice that Sanders denied saying that a woman "couldn't" be president. He did not deny saying that a woman could not be elected. A few have already picked up on this distinction, such as Melanie Pryce in this publication. The latter assumption, of course, is pure speculation. Nobody knows who is "electable" until they are actually elected. Most people thought Trump had zero chance of being elected in 2016, and indeed, he did lose the popular vote. The female candidate won the election. However, she did not win the Electoral College, as we all know. So again, the entire country is faced with the problem of trying to second-guess how three states will vote. None of those three are known to be hotbeds of feminism. The Democrats in those states tend to be Republican Lites, not Democrats in the FDR sense of the party. So, once again, we are confronted with the fact that the entire country can be controlled by a minority, if that minority wins strategic states. And if that occurs again, you can bet that there will be massive political unrest from the majority, who are sick and tired of being under the thumb of people we profoundly disagree with. This conflict will only grow with time. Electing Warren or Sanders will help to assuage the conflict. Denying the majority again the right to rule itself will only exacerbate the problem.

The problem with our politics - with who we are becoming as a society - is that we're always in the mode of anxiously and breathlessly dealing with an emotionally reactive present moment...and rarely do we take a step back and look at the "big picture."

What wins election, especially presidential elections, is a candidate and the candidate’s staff who are able to successfully create and manage that candidate’s projection of an image as President of the United States. Think back to how Obama came out of nowhere as a junior Senator to eventually create a sense of inevitability for himself. He wasn’t there until, bit by bit, he became the one. His campaign artfully created in enough voters’ minds that he was the best choice for President. Of course there are thousands of steps along the way in what is a very complex process, but electability isn’t just something a candidate has, it is something a candidate creates.

So a woman is electable, and to think otherwise is a first step in consigning oneself to the trash bin of history. But that woman, whoever she is, will have to smartly create what will become her own inevitability with a smart campaign that builds a winning image. In fact, that is exactly what Trump did. The job now also involves pointing out all the obvious flaws in the Trump image. Perhaps a woman candidate is the best choice for reminding everyone of the obvious: that the emperor has no clothes.

I wish discussions of gender could reach deeper into their origins where they lay cemented in our unconscious. You don't believe me?   Look at the stubborn irrational hatred that continues to be flung at Hilary Clinton.   And for what?   What crimes has she committed that would warrant the vitriolic hatred?   She's a woman, ergo she is suspect and reviled.   I've asked moderates why they voted for Trump in 2016 and all of them - women as well as men - respond with "he was better than the alternative."  Really?   And then when I ask them what she did, they can't come up with anything substantive.   They rattled off "Benghazi" or "emails."   And when I point out that no other Sec. of State has been made culpable for an embassy attack, I get blank stares.   Their hatred of Clinton is irrational because what they hate about her is that she is female.   It's this roiling of unexamined bigotry that has to be resolved before a woman can win.   And I don't know how long that will take.

My pledge: I will not vote for or withhold my vote for any candidate based on their being a man or a woman.   I will consider voting against any candidate who characterizes this election as a choice between a man or a woman, be they a man or a woman. Let's stick with the issues.

I'm no Republican, but I dont want to spend my life "at the DMV" or on hold with the IRS. I'm a moderate Democrat because I believe government can help us and is essential to the common good, but too much government cannot help us. Government should be like prescription drugs: of course they can and do help people, but we should take as little as possible and stop taking them as soon as possible. The Republicans have been attacking and tearing down government for too long and too much, but I see a risk we will oversteer with a candidate like Warren or Sanders, endorsed by AOC. That approach will lose, because Trump is a stronger and better fighter than she is. (Not because she is a woman, but because she is the person who she is.)

“Look at the men on this stage. Collectively, they have lost 10 elections.”

Eyes on the prize.

"There was a memorable moment when Sanders sought to correct Warren on her 30-year claim, noting that he’d defeated a Republican in 1990, and she did some quick, out-loud arithmetic to determine that 1990 was, well, 30 years ago! "

That was my favorite moment of the debate.  There's nothing like a fact to win an argument, unless, of course, we're talking about politicians whose idea of "truth" is beyond squishy.

The expected fireworks between Warren and Sanders ("You lied!!  No, you lied") never happened, Thank God.  The last thing Democrats needed was a food fight on something as important as gender, considering the makeup of the party.

I wish we could put this "can't win" notion to rest, but I suspect until a woman wins the highest office, we can't.  Like Frank Bruni, I have no idea who is the best choice to beat Trump in our era of high-stakes partisanship, vanishing truth, and-let's face it--misogny. 

But female competence, from Pelosi to last night's candidates, is no longer in question.

While it may be impossible to untangle how sexism weighs on a candidate's prospects, we can join in admiring the talent and ability of Elizabeth Warren. While nervousness and anxiety makes us dither at the edge of the stage, she is doing excellent work.

It's a good thing to remember history, to re-tell how doubt gnawed away at the edges of that Roman Catholic candidate, that African American candidate. as if every "otherness" were a kind of disability at the top, where a chorus of shining white male faces still create a daunting forcefield to the imagination.

(Marianne Williamson, on the other hand, would have been a disaster.)
So, to paraphrase Martin Luther King, it is the quality of a person's character rather than race or gender (or any other "identity") that determines one's fitness for office, and any of those 6 people on the debate stage is leagues ahead of Trump in that department.

There is no doubt that misogyny is alive and well in the country. Nonetheless, increasing numbers of women have both run for and achieved high elective office, and the number is growing. Whether they are better than men is not the right question to ask, because the answer is that they are, at least, just as good.

But maybe they are better. They are a product of their own life experiences, and due to things like gender bias, glass ceilings and other factors, they bring a perspective that differs, by its nature, and likely in a positive way, from that of the old boys club. 

Women have long done a lot of heavy lifting in this country, and around the world. Successful female leaders have included the likes of Gold Meier, to mention only one, and scores of others in both government and corporate life. 

No, gender alone should not and does not signify which candidate is electable and capable of serving as an effective and successful president.
